summary.title: Careers Wales dataset
summary.abstract: Careers Wales dataset

documentation.description:
Careers Wales dataset.

The data supplied to SAIL represents interactions and services provided by Careers Wales to clients throughout Wales over the period 01/04/2012 to 31/03/2020. At the start of this period, the Careers Wales had just been formed from six regional Careers companies, and their CRM system was initially populated with imports from the preceding companies’ systems. Between 2012 and the present Careers Wales has worked to rationalise the varied approaches to recording, enhance the quality and suitability of the data they gather, and to simplify the data entry requirements for their staff as far as possible. Therefore users of the data will very likely notice changes over time in the nature of the data.

Careers Wales stores information on all its interactions, services provided, etc. as entities called histories. Within their CRM, different on-screen fields can be enabled or disabled for different history types – therefore a history representing a Group Session would contain information on the duration of the session, the topic and the venue; whereas a history for a Traineeship Referral Form completion would not display any of these fields.

All the numerically coded columns in Careers Wales’ supplied data can be decoded via the accompanying lookup file - HISTORIES_LOOKUP_1545_20200821.CSV.

qualifiedRelation: Linkable at the person level to any dataset with SAIL anonymised linkage field

dataClasses.description:
Careers Wales Histories/ Activity table.

Careers Wales stores information on all its interactions, services provided, etc. as entities called histories. Within their CRM, different on-screen fields can be enabled or disabled for different history types – therefore a history representing a Group Session would contain information on the duration of the session, the topic and the venue; whereas a history for a Traineeship Referral Form completion would not display any of these fields.
dataClasses.name: HISTORIES_DATA_20200821

dataElements.description: Encrypted Opportunity ID. Used for a variety of purposes. Opportunities can be job vacancies, or Apprenticeship or Traineeship opportunities (e.g. in the case of a Traineeship Referral Form history). They’re also used as a way to represent the topic of interactions like Group Sessions.
dataElements.name: OPPORTUNITY_ID_E

dataElements.description:
Code indicating the Service Required.
During Year 9, Careers Advisers in school begin to prioritise the clients in the year group based on their likely service requirements. This is initially achieved via a tool called Career Check, but can be reviewed and amended at any point if required (via the recording of a subsequent history). Advisers record the likely service requirements using a type B category S history (‘Service Required’, category 27 in the lookup table), with this flag(s) populated to indicate the client’s likely needs. The method of indicating the service required has differed over the years and therefore this is being indicated over multiple fields
dataElements.name: FLAG_SERVICE_REQUIRED_6

dataElements.description:
Activity Category code. In Careers Wales’ CMS, histories all have a ‘type’ and ‘category’, which defines the nature of the interaction. Only a subset of all the categories used have been included in the export; those which represent Careers Wales interacting with the client in some way. As the data spans a period where Careers Wales were rationalising many aspects of their data capture, many of the categories used will not span the entire period. Broadly speaking, they can be summarised into a few basic types of interaction:
• One-to-one: an interview where a two-way discussion takes place between the adviser and the client. Parents or guardians may be present.
• Group session: an interaction where more than one client is present. Although two-way discussion may still take place, these are typically more often presentation-type interactions.
• Annual/Transition Review: for clients who are Statemented, School Action or School Action Plus, a Transition or Annual Review takes place each year, to which the client’s Careers Adviser is invited.
• Advocacy/Liaison: representing work done on behalf of the client, where there client is not usually present (or at least actively participating). This may include contacting WBL providers or colleges on behalf of the client, researching job opportunities or writing letters of support etc.
• Email to/from client: an email generated from IO to the client, or a reply from the client (automatically imported into an IO history)
• Text to/from client: an text message generated from IO to the client, or a reply from the client (automatically imported into an IO history)
dataElements.name: ACTIVITY_CATEGORY

dataElements.description:
Code indicating the Service Required.
During Year 9, Careers Advisers in school begin to prioritise the clients in the year group based on their likely service requirements. This is initially achieved via a tool called Career Check, but can be reviewed and amended at any point if required (via the recording of a subsequent history). Advisers record the likely service requirements using a type B category S history (‘Service Required’, category 27 in the lookup table), with this flag(s) populated to indicate the client’s likely needs. The method of indicating the service required has differed over the years and therefore this is being indicated over multiple fields
dataElements.name: FLAG_SERVICE_REQUIRED_1

dataElements.description: Client Status code. The status of the client at the time of the interaction. Note that some statuses are now labelled ‘DO NOT USE’ as they’ve been discontinued – however, for older histories they would have been valid status codes.
dataElements.name: CLIENT_STATUS

dataElements.description: Code indicating the Channel. The Channel of an interaction describes the medium over which the majority of the interaction took place. Traditionally this would have been face-to-face or telephone for One-to-ones, and face-to-face for group interactions – however, Careers Wales can also interact with clients via text and email, via written communications or via internet-based systems.
dataElements.name: FLAG_CHANNEL

dataElements.description: Date when the data made available i.e. date of loading
dataElements.name: AVAIL_FROM_DT

dataElements.description:
Code indicating the Service Required.
During Year 9, Careers Advisers in school begin to prioritise the clients in the year group based on their likely service requirements. This is initially achieved via a tool called Career Check, but can be reviewed and amended at any point if required (via the recording of a subsequent history). Advisers record the likely service requirements using a type B category S history (‘Service Required’, category 27 in the lookup table), with this flag(s) populated to indicate the client’s likely needs. The method of indicating the service required has differed over the years and therefore this is being indicated over multiple fields
dataElements.name: FLAG_SERVICE_REQUIRED_2

dataElements.description:
Encrypted Cluster ID. These IDs are system-generated identifiers that work in a slightly different way to the Encypted History IDs. They are used in two scenarios:
• Where an activity is being delivered to more than one client at once. If Careers Wales are delivering a group activity – e.g. a ‘Choices at 14+’ presentation to a whole year group in school – they record a history against every client who attended, so the service to the individual can be accurately represented. However, to accurately monitor Careers Wales’ resource input in delivering services, they also need to count these histories as a single event in some cases. This is achieved by assigning the same non-zero clusterid to all the attendances for a particular session.
• Where an activity or service is batch-created. Careers Wales CMS has the capability to text or email clients directly, and advisers can either use this to contact clients individually, or can bulk-text or email them – e.g. to promote an upcoming Careers Fair. Where histories are created in bulk the clusterid is again used to identify the fact that the matching histories are related.
dataElements.name: CLUSTERID_E

dataElements.description: Code indicating the Service Delivered. For One-to-one interactions, advisers can deliver a number of different services depending on the client’s needs, or the project under which the service is delivered. ‘Information’, ‘Advice’ and ‘Guidance’ represent interactions of increasing complexity (note that only qualified Careers Advisers can deliver ‘Guidance’), and ‘Activate 1-2-1 Support’ describes specific support provided to clients in education under the Activate project.
dataElements.name: FLAG_SERVICE_DELIVERED

dataElements.description: The date and (where available) time on which the history took effect. Note that advisers can specify the start date for activities, so there can be a significant period between an activity taking place and it being recorded.
dataElements.name: DATETIME_START

dataElements.description:
Code indicating the Service Required.

dataElements.description: Parent Present code. Indicates whether the client’s parent was present at the interaction.
dataElements.name: PARENT_PRESENT

dataElements.description: Encrypted System ID. A numeric ID used to match file 2 data to a file 1 individual.
dataElements.name: SYSTEM_ID_E

dataElements.description: Code indicating the Group Year. Although a client’s year group is primarily captured via the ‘client_status’ field, for Group Sessions it’s possible that groups delivered in school may have a mixture of year groups present. This field is used as an indicator of the intended year group for the session – e.g. where a Year 9 client attends a session intended as Year 10 provision, this ensures the work is still identifiable as a KS4 service where necessary.
dataElements.name: FLAG_GROUP_YEAR

dataElements.description: Code indicating the Review Type. Statemented, School Action and School Action Plus clients general have a Transition Review in Year 9, and Annual Reviews in Year 10 and 11. This flag is simply used to distinguish the two types of Review.
dataElements.name: FLAG_REVIEW_TYPE

dataElements.description:
Code indicating the Service Required.
During Year 9, Careers Advisers in school begin to prioritise the clients in the year group based on their likely service requirements. This is initially achieved via a tool called Career Check, but can be reviewed and amended at any point if required (via the recording of a subsequent history). Advisers record the likely service requirements using a type B category S history (‘Service Required’, category 27 in the lookup table), with this flag(s) populated to indicate the client’s likely needs. The method of indicating the service required has differed over the years and therefore this is being indicated over multiple fields
dataElements.name: FLAG_SERVICE_REQUIRED_7

dataElements.description: The number of attendees at a group session. Although group session attendance is recorded against the individual client, in some cases Careers Wales either do not know some of the attendees, and do not have enough information about them to create a client record; or the session was of a sufficient size that it wasn’t practical to find or create client records for every attendee (e.g. Careers Conventions and other large events). Therefore, although the ‘attendees’ will generally correspond to the number of other histories sharing the same clusterid, this field allows Careers Wales to accurately represent sessions where this was not the case.
dataElements.name: ATTENDEES

dataElements.description: Encrypted History ID. The primary key field of the History table, this simply uniquely identifies any given History record. History IDs are system-generated sequential integers, and do not encode any information about the client or the service.
dataElements.name: HISTORYID_E

dataElements.description: Duration in minutes of the activity (where applicable).
dataElements.name: DURATION_MINUTES

dataElements.description: Code indicating the Review Attendance. Although a client’s Careers Adviser should be invited to every Transition or Annual Review, they are not always able to attend. We record the history for every review so we know when it took place – however, this flag is used to indicate whether the adviser attended or not.
dataElements.name: FLAG_REVIEW_ATTENDANCE

dataElements.description: Organisation code. The organisation to which the activity should be assigned. Originally this was used somewhat inconsistently, but in the more recently recorded histories this should reflect the Careers Wales team delivering that particular interaction.
dataElements.name: ORGANISATION

dataElements.description: Code indicating the Language in which the service was primarily delivered.
dataElements.name: FLAG_LANGUAGE

dataElements.description: Date time given history was entered.
dataElements.name: DATETIME_ENTERED

access.accessRequestCost: Data provision is free from SAIL. Overall project costing depends on the number of people that require access to the SAIL Gateway, the activities that SAIL needs to complete (e.g. loading non-standard datasets), data refreshes, analytical work required, disclosure control process, and special case technological requirements.

summary.title: Estimating Chronic Respiratory Disease burden in adults in Asian LMICs
summary.abstract: Informed by a review of existing protocols used in Low and Middle-Income Countries to identify Chronic Respiratory Diseases, we will undertake a pilot survey to explore feasibility of using screening process in Bangladesh, India, Malaysia and Pakistan.

documentation.description:
Informed by a scoping review of existing questionnaires and protocols used in Low- and Middle-Income Countries (LMICs) to identify Chronic Respiratory Diseasess, we will undertake a pilot survey to explore feasibility of using screening process in four countries (Bangladesh, India, Malaysia, and Pakistan). Our pilot findings will inform a future fully powered survey to determine the prevalence of asthma, COPD and other CRD in the community, using robust random sampling strategies, and quality assured spirometry undertaken by field workers.

For further details, see: https://www.ed.ac.uk/usher/respire/chronic-respiratory-disorders/estimating-chronic-respiratory-disease-burden

accessRights: Access is managed on a project-by-project basis. Contact the RESPIRE team: https://www.ed.ac.uk/usher/respire/about/projects

summary.title: Labour Force Survey (Household)
summary.abstract: The primary purpose of the Labour Force Survey (LFS) is "providing good quality point in time and change estimates for various labour market outputs and related topics” (National Statistics Quality Review (NSQR) of Labour Force Survey 2014).

documentation.description: The primary purpose of the Labour Force Survey (LFS) is "providing good quality point in time and change estimates for various labour market outputs and related topics” (National Statistics Quality Review (NSQR) of Labour Force Survey 2014). The labour market covers all aspects of people's work, including the education and training needed to equip them for work, the jobs themselves, job-search for those out of work and income from work and benefits.  Output from the LFS is quarterly since 1992. Each quarter’s sample is made up of 5 waves. The sample is made up of approximately 40,000 responding UK households and 100,000 individuals per quarter. This dataset only coveres household responses. Respondents are interviewed for 5 successive waves at 3-monthly intervals and 20% of the sample is replaced every quarter. The LFS is intended to be representative of the entire population of the UK.

access.accessService:
The Office for National Statistics Secure Research Service (SRS) gives accredited researchers secure access to de-identified, unpublished data in order to work on research projects for the public good.   Most datasets are available to access through remote access to the SRS. In some instances, the data can only be accessed from an approved safe setting. 
 For more information,visit: https://www.ons.gov.uk/aboutus/whatwedo/statistics/requestingstatistics/approvedresearcherscheme

summary.title: Pillar 1 - England (Second Generation Surveillance Systems)
summary.abstract: The Second Generation Surveillance System (SGSS) is the national laboratory reporting system used in England to capture routine laboratory data on mainly infectious diseases and antimicrobial resistance.

documentation.description:
The Second Generation Surveillance System (SGSS) is the national laboratory reporting system used in England to capture routine laboratory data on mainly infectious diseases and antimicrobial resistance. The Respiratory DataMart has been used to monitor major respiratory viruses circulating in England bringing together this data from PHE laboratories in England since 2009. Both SGSS and Respiratory DataMart have been adapted and combined to capture detections of SARS-CoV-2.

SARS-CoV-2 testing started in UK laboratories on 24 January 2020. This data is reported through a combination of laboratory systems (SGSS and Respiratory DataMart). The majority of testing to date has been offered to those in hospital with a medical need as well as NHS key workers, rather than the general population. Confirmed cases therefore represent the typical population of people with severe disease rather than all of those who get infected.

summary.title: Secondary Uses Services
summary.abstract:
Single, comprehensive repository for healthcare data in England which enables a range of reporting and analyses to support the NHS in the delivery of healthcare services. Used primarily by Providers and Commissioners to drive system of payments.
Data cov

documentation.description:
Single, comprehensive repository for healthcare data in England which enables a range of reporting and analyses to support the NHS in the delivery of healthcare services. Used primarily by Providers and Commissioners to drive system of payments.
Data covers:
* Finished general episodes admitted patient care
* Outpatients
* A&E attendances.

dataElements.description: This holds an unbundled HRG produced during the grouping process. Fills up with nationally PRICED HRGs first, then as many un-priced HRGs as can be accommodated, up to a maximum of 12.
dataElements.name: Unbundled HRG 1

dataElements.description: The submitted organisation code of the organisation commissioning the health care.
dataElements.name: Commissioner Code (Original Data)

dataElements.description:
This is the number of pounds (£) which will be added to the tariff due to (elective OR non-Elective) Market Force Factor.
Eg (Tariff ) * MFF
£100 * 1.060012 = £106 Therefore “6” will appear in this field
dataElements.name: MFF Adjustment

dataElements.description:
This is a submitted age at the date on which the activity took place.
This value is taken from the pseudo-dominant episode for multi-episode spells.
dataElements.name: Age At CDS Activity Date

dataElements.description: In addition to standard Specialised Service Codes, in 2010-11 it may be possible for a spell to be eligible for an additional “Specialised Service Code” where Best Practice criteria has been met.
dataElements.name: Best Practice SSC

dataElements.description: The national tariff trimpoint of the spell HRG.
dataElements.name: PbR Spell Trimpoint Days

dataElements.description:
Indicates if this spell may be eligible for applying DH tariff adjustments.
Values are "Y" or "N"
NOT NULL if Spell Type = CHILD 
NOTE: Spells within a pathway may be flagged as ineligible ("N") but this does not necessarily make the entire pathway ineligible.
dataElements.name: RAP DH Tariff Adjustment Child

dataElements.description: This is the sum of all unbundled HRG prices, to give a total unbundled HRG value.  Refers to HRGs with National unbundled tariffs.
dataElements.name: Aggregate Unbundled Adjustment National

dataElements.description:
This identifies the destination of a patient on completing a Hospital Provider Spell.
This value is taken from the last episode for multi-episode spells.
dataElements.name: Discharge Destination (Hospital Provider Spell)

dataElements.description:
The category of a patient derived for the spell by looking at all the episodes in the spell.
If  all the episodes in the spell have the same ADMINISTRATIVE CATEGORY (AT START OF EPISODE) then that value is used. If episodes have a mix of 01 and 02 codes ONLY, the value is set to "Mixed - NHS/Private", if they have a mix of any other codes then its set to "Mixed - Other".
dataElements.name: Administrative Category (Derived)

dataElements.description:
This is the non- elective Market Force Factor held in reference data (REF_PBR_MARKET_FORCES_FACTOR) for the provider of this spell.
Eg 1.060012
dataElements.name: Applied MFF Non Elective

dataElements.description: This is the spell level core HRG used for tariff application.
dataElements.name: Spell Core HRG

dataElements.description:
This is the highest ranking, eligible specialised service code (SSC) - from maximum of 5 produced as an output of grouping process. Highest ranking is taken from the hierarchy held in reference data.
Not in Data Dictionary (DD). May contain NULL.
dataElements.name: Significant Specialised Service Code

dataElements.description: Age at Start of Pseudo-Dominant Episode used for SUS spell processing.  Aligns with HRG Grouper spell age derivation.
dataElements.name: Spell Age

dataElements.description: Indicates whether meeting the BPT criteria influences the tariff displayed
dataElements.name: BPT Indicator 3 Action

dataElements.description: This is a £ value, populated if tariff Financial Adjustment top up has been applied within the spell (Alteplase etc.).
dataElements.name: Tariff Financial Adjustment National

dataElements.description: Specialised service adjustment
dataElements.name: Tariff Service Adjustment National

dataElements.description: A number used to identify an NHS service agreement. Also used within PbR to exclude records from having a tariff applied through the use of an equals ('=') sign
dataElements.name: Commissioner Serial No (Agreement No)

dataElements.description: Note - this is an uplift to be included on the extract when 1 of the "spare" adjustments are employed.
dataElements.name: Tariff Adjustment Future Use_2 National

dataElements.description: Used from 13/14 onwards. For spells admitted before 01/04/2013 and discharged on or after 01/04/2013 this will be the PCT code of the organisation deemed to have ceded liability for activity from the GP practice (Code would formerly have appeared in the GP_PRACTICE_PCT_D field).
dataElements.name: Spare 3

dataElements.description: A pseudonymised value which is used to identify a patient uniquely within a healthcare provider. Pseudonymisation relies on the submitted local patient identifier.
dataElements.name: Local Patient Identifier (Pseudonymised)

dataElements.description: The treatment function under which the patient is treated during the spell. For multi episode spells this value is taken from the pseudo-dominant episode (spell report flag = '1').
dataElements.name: Treatment Function Code

dataElements.description: Contains the outward portion of a patient's postcode (ie all characters to the left of the space)
dataElements.name: Postcode Sector of Usual Address

dataElements.description: This is the day case tariff for the HRG.   This is obtained from reference data and does not include MFF or any other adjustment. This is a £ value.
dataElements.name: Tariff Day Case National

dataElements.description:
This is a classification of patients who have been admitted to hospital (e.g. ordinary admission, day case admission, regular day attender etc.)
This value is taken from the pseudo-dominant episode for multi-episode spells.
dataElements.name: Patient Classification

dataElements.description:
This is the submitted Provider code before testing against reference files.
This value is taken from the last episode for multi-episode spells.
dataElements.name: Provider Code (Original Data)

dataElements.description: Next specialised service code (SSC) in ascending order from maximum of 5 produced as an output of grouping process. Not in DD. May be NULL
dataElements.name: Specialised Service Code 4

dataElements.description: see Unbundled HRG 1 description
dataElements.name: Unbundled HRG 10

dataElements.description: For multi-episode spells, this is the Primary Procedure (OPCS) code from the pseudo-dominant episode in the spell.

dataElements.description:
This is an output from the grouper at Spell level.
This is the 1st secondary diagnosis (ICD) code from the same episode as spell primary diagnosis (ICD).
dataElements.name: Spell Secondary Diagnosis

dataElements.description: Sum of all Spell Adult Critical Care Days from episodes included in Spell. i.e. does not include days from excluded episodes.

dataElements.name: Spell PCC Length Of Stay

dataElements.description: see Unbundled HRG 1 description
dataElements.name: Unbundled HRG 4

dataElements.description: A pseudonymised value which is used to identify a patient uniquely within the PbR data. Pseudonymisation relies on the submitted NHS number.
dataElements.name: NHS Number (Pseudonymised)

dataElements.description:
This is an output from the grouper at Spell level
This is the spell dominant procedure (OPCS) code as identified by the grouper. This may not have been submitted as a primary procedure on any of the episodes in the spell.
dataElements.name: Spell Dominant Procedure

dataElements.description: The ethnicity of a patient.

dataElements.description: Tariff applied to spell for a Long Stay adjustment. This is a £ value.

dataElements.description:
The gender of a patient.
This value is taken from the pseudo-dominant episode for multi-episode spells.
dataElements.name: Gender Code

dataElements.description:
The organisation code of the organisation providing the healthcare.
This value is taken from the last episode for multi-episode spells.
dataElements.name: Organisation Code (Code of Provider)

dataElements.description: Total National payment for spell – inclusive of all top-ups and adjustments including MFF.

dataElements.description: This is the Programme Budgeting Category produced by the grouper for the spell.

dataElements.description: This is a SUS derived PCT code based on a patient's postcode.

dataElements.name: Unbundled HRG 12

dataElements.description: This identifies the method of admission for a Hospital Provider Spell.

dataElements.name: Spell Exclusion Reason

dataElements.description:
This is the Short Stay emergency tariff for the HRG.  This is obtained from reference data and does not include MFF or any other adjustment.
Please note – SSE tariff is only applicable to a subset of Admission methods (this list is controlled in SUS by reference data).
dataElements.name: Tariff Short Stay Emergency National

dataElements.description: First specialised service code (SSC) in ascending order from maximum of 5 produced as an output of grouping process. This may NOT be the same as the most significant eligible SSC. Not in DD. May be NULL
dataElements.name: Specialised Service Code 1

dataElements.description: This is the initial tariff for the Core Spell HRG before any adjustment is applied. This is a £ value obtained from reference data.

This field will be populated with the content of the following field:

Tariff Total Payment National

This is because non-mandatory and local tariffs are not currently applied within SUS.
dataElements.name: PbR Final Tariff

dataElements.description:
This is a submitted PCT code derived from a patient's postcode.
For data submitted using CDS 6.2 (post 01/04/13) this value will be populated using the attribute ORGANISATION CODE (RESIDENCE RESPONSIBILITY). For data submitted using CDS 6.1 this value is populated using the attribute ORGANISATION CODE (PCT OF RESIDENCE). Therefore, for data submitted to SUS after 01/04/2013 the value displayed may be a PCT or a CCG code depending on the schema version being used for submissions and the value submitted.
dataElements.name: Organisation Code (PCT of Residence)

dataElements.description: This field identifies what was planned to happen to a patient. This value is taken from the first episode for multi-episode spells.

dataElements.description:
Indicates if spell is a potential CHILD spell in a Readmission Pathway (RAP) and will only be flagged for spells where admission sub-type is 'EMR' and PbR Qualified Indicator = 0 regardless of whether there is a 'Parent' spell or whether the spell is part of a Readmissions pathway
Will only be populated with 'C' for Child only where admission sub-type is 'EMR' (Note: will not necessarily reconcile to the Readmissions extract as will not necessarily be part of a pathway)  The purpose of this indicator is to support calculation of emergency admission thresholds.

summary.title: Care Home Dataset
summary.abstract: This database contains residential and geographical information data about care homes in Wales.

documentation.description: This database contains residential and geographical information data about care homes in Wales.

access.accessRequestCost: Data provision is free from SAIL. Overall project costing depends on the number of people that require access to the SAIL Gateway, the activities that SAIL needs to complete (e.g. loading non-standard datasets), data refreshes, analytical work required, disclosure control process, and special case technological requirements.

qualifiedRelation: Linkable with other datasets with a residential anonymised linkage field (RALF).

dataClasses.description: Care Home Residential Anonymised Linkage Field data. Contains geographic information data about care homes.

summary.title: UK Cystic Fibrosis Registry (CYFI)
summary.abstract: The UK Cystic Fibrosis Registry is a national, secure, centralized database sponsored and managed by the Cystic Fibrosis Trust, with UK National Health Service (NHS) research ethics approval and consent from each person for whom data are collected. First

documentation.description: The UK Cystic Fibrosis Registry is a national, secure, centralized database sponsored and managed by the Cystic Fibrosis Trust, with UK National Health Service (NHS) research ethics approval and consent from each person for whom data are collected. First established in 1995, it records longitudinal health data on all people with cystic fibrosis (CF) in England, Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland, and to date has captured data on over 12 000 individuals.

access.dataController: Cystic Fibrosis Trust, with UK National Health Service (NHS)
access.accessRequestCost: Data provision is free from SAIL. Overall project costing depends on the number of people that require access to the SAIL Gateway, the activities that SAIL needs to complete (e.g. loading non-standard datasets), data refreshes, analytical work required, disclosure control process, and special case technological requirements.

dataElements.description: Anonymised Linked Field Match Percentage.  This number is a match % score from probabalistic matching, when joining together anonymised data. This linkage process consists of matching against the Welsh Demographic Service by NHS number, where a valid number exists, and where there is no valid number then matching is attempted using first name, surname, date of birth, and postcode. This is an artificial score with no real-world meaning; i.e. a match of .99 does not mean there is a 99% chance the match is correct.  This number is assigned when deriving the Encrypted Anonymised Linking Field.
dataElements.name: ALF_MATCH_PCT

dataElements.description: Encrypted Unique CYFI ID reference number for data linkage.

dataElements.description: Anonymised Linking Field (ALF), Encrypted.  This field is derived from by double encryption after splitting demographic information and clinical information; the first encryption occurs in NHS Wales Informatics Service (NWIS), and the second in SAIL. If the NHS number is not supplied in the data extract, then matching methods are applied; please refer to ALF_MTCH_PCT.

summary.title: COVID antigen testing - Pillar 1
summary.abstract: Details of completed (processed) COVID-19 antigen tests carried out in NHS hospitals in NI

documentation.description:
This dataset is extracted from the Laboratory Information Systems in Northern Ireland hospitals on a daily basis. It contains details of COVID-19 antigen tests carried out in each of the hospital laboratories, including those processed on behalf of primary care, social care and community settings.
https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/coronavirus-covid-19-testing-data-methodology/covid-19-testing-data-methodology-note

summary.title: Labour Force Survey (Longitudinal)
summary.abstract: The primary purpose of the Labour Force Survey (LFS) is "providing good quality point in time and change estimates for various labour market outputs and related topics” (National Statistics Quality Review (NSQR) of Labour Force Survey 2014).

documentation.description: The primary purpose of the Labour Force Survey (LFS) is "providing good quality point in time and change estimates for various labour market outputs and related topics” (National Statistics Quality Review (NSQR) of Labour Force Survey 2014). The labour market covers all aspects of people's work, including the education and training needed to equip them for work, the jobs themselves, job-search for those out of work and income from work and benefits.  Output from the LFS is quarterly since 1992. Each quarter’s sample is made up of 5 waves. The sample is made up of approximately 40,000 responding UK households and 100,000 individuals per quarter. Respondents are interviewed for 5 successive waves at 3-monthly intervals and 20% of the sample is replaced every quarter. The LFS is intended to be representative of the entire population of the UK. This dataset is the lognitudinal LFS data

access.accessService:
The Office for National Statistics Secure Research Service (SRS) gives accredited researchers secure access to de-identified, unpublished data in order to work on research projects for the public good.  For more information,visit: https://www.ons.gov.uk/aboutus/whatwedo/statistics/requestingstatistics/approvedresearcherscheme

summary.title: General Acute Inpatient and Day Case - Scottish Morbidity Record (SMR01)
summary.abstract: The General / Acute and Inpatient Day Case dataset (SMR01) collects episode level data on hospital inpatient and day case discharges from acute specialities from hospitals in Scotland.

documentation.description: The dataset contains patient identifiers such as name, date of birth, Community Health Index number, NHS number, postcode and ethnicity and episode management data. Of particular interest to researchers would be variables such as where the episode took place, admission type (includes patient injury classifications such as self-inflicted or home accident), waiting times, patients condition (as classified under ICD-10), operations, and discharge location. A wide variety of geographical data is also included in the dataset including Scottish Index of Multiple Deprivation and Carstairs measures, census output area, NHS Board, Electoral Ward and Parliamentary constituency.

coverage.pathway: All of secondary care in relation to general acute inpatient and day cases.
coverage.spatial: The General / Acute Inpatient and Day Case data covers all residents in Scotland that receive care in hospital and general acute specialities.

dataClasses.description:
A SMR01 is generated for patients receiving care in the General/ Acute specialties when the following events occur:

Inpatients and day cases are admitted to NHS hospitals from locations external to the NHS.
Inpatients and day cases are admitted to contracted NHS beds in non-NHS institutions.
Inpatients and day cases change specialty (with or without a change of consultant) when:
An Inpatient transfers to become an Inpatient in another specialty in the same hospital.
An inpatient becomes a Day Case in another specialty during the inpatient stay.
A day case transfers to become an Inpatient in another specialty (except when the day case episode is during an inpatient stay and the patient is transferring back to the original consultant).
A day case transfers back to resume an Inpatient stay but does NOT transfer back to the original consultant for medical reasons.
Inpatients and day cases transfer from another NHS hospital (including contracted NHS beds in non-NHS institutions).
Inpatients and day cases change consultant for medical reasons within the same specialty when :
An inpatient transfers as an Inpatient to the care of a different consultant for medical reasons in the same specialty in the same hospital.
An inpatient becomes a Day Case in the same specialty under a different consultant for medical reasons during the inpatient stay.
A day case transfers to become an Inpatient under the care of a different consultant in the same specialty for medical reasons (except when the day case episode is during an inpatient stay and the patient is transferring back to the original consultant).
A day case transfers back to resume an Inpatient stay in the same specialty but does NOT transfer back to the original consultant for medical reasons.
Inpatients move into and/or out of one of the valid significant facilities.
Inpatients return to hospital having been on pass for more than 5 days.
Note: Items in bold denote the patient type of the further SMR record generated by the transfers described in these categories.
dataClasses.name: General Acute Inpatients/Day Cases

Mandatory

Definition
A Significant Facility is a type of clinical facility which is identified for clinical and/or costing purposes.

Recording Rules

An SMR01 is NOT raised for a change of ward only UNLESS there is a change to a ward with a DIFFERENT Significant Facility code value (as listed above).
Codes and Values: Significant Facility

For specific Significant Facility Codes valid for SMR01 - see the SMR01 CRIB Sheet

Generic Definition
Significant facility
dataElements.name: Significant Facilities and Codes for SMR01

dataElements.description:
Format
Characters

Field Length
3

Priority
Mandatory

Definitions

Specialty
A Specialty is defined as a division of medicine or dentistry covering a specific area of clinical activity and identified within one of the Royal Colleges or Faculties.

Click here for a complete list of Specialties

Discipline
A Discipline is a non-medical profession related to healthcare, for which a formal training leading to a recognised professional qualification is undertaken. Examples of disciplines are physiotherapy, nursing, pharmacology.

Recording Rules
This field should be coded to the Specialty/Discipline of the consultant/GP/HCP who is in charge of the patient episode. If the consultant is formally recognised and contracted to work in more than one specialty then the patients problem or condition should dictate the specialty.

Note that this is the ONLY rule for completing this field. The designation of the beds is not used.

Specialty/Discipline comprises four characters, the first three of which are allocated by ISD for each specialty, and is mandatory for completion. For the majority of Specialty/Discipline codes, which are two characters, the 3rd character space must be left blank if the 4th character extension is used. The 4th character is an Optional extension of the code for local special interests.

The Specialty/Discipline code should be entered in the character spaces provided and left justified.

Points to Note

A separate SMR record is prepared when a patient changes Specialty, Significant Facility or Consultant on medical grounds
GPs: Patients under the care of a GP in a GP hospital must be given the Specialty code E12 (GP other than Obstetrics) regardless of whether the patients are in a short stay or long stay facility.
Staff Wards: The Specialty recorded is that of the consultant/GP in charge of the patient. Record Significant Facility as 11 (Other: including all Standard Specialty Wards, Clinical Facility 1K, Day Bed Unit 1J).
Younger Physically Disabled: Record the Specialty of the consultant in charge of the patient, which will usually be geriatric medicine. Record Significant Facility as 18 (Ward for Younger Physically Disabled) or 1E (Long Stay Unit for Care of the Elderly).
See additional notes under Significant Facility.
For SMR02 records this should reflect the speciality of the person who was responsible for the care for the mother on original admission.
Example 1- If the mother was originally admitted under the care of a midwife in an Alongside Midwifery Unit (AMU) or Freestanding Midwifery Unit (FMU), then the midwifery specialty should be recorded in this section, irrespective of whether the mother was then transferred to an Obstetric unit during labour/delivery. When a transfer has occurred Speciality should NOT be attributed to Obstetrics.

Example 2 - If the mother was originally admitted under the care of a Consultant in an Obstetric Unit then the Obstetrics specialty should be recorded here.

Cross Checks

Specialty is checked against Location Code.
Specialty is checked against Consultant.
Specialty is checked against the Patients Age (at Date of Admission).
Specialty is checked against Duration of Stay calculated between Date of Admission and Date of Discharge.
Specialty is checked against Record Type
Specialty is checked against Significant Facility.
SMR Validation - Specialty/Discipline

Location Code
Significant Facility
SMR Record Type

Common names
Registered GP Practice

Definition
Registered General Medical Practitioners provide general medical services to the population either in partnership with other GMPs or on a single-handed basis. The term GP practice covers both partnerships and single-handed practices. Each GP practice in Scotland is identified by a unique GP practice code. The practice code is a four-digit code plus a check digit with ranges of codes allocated to each Health Board.
(Scottish Morbidity Record - NHS Information Services)

Recording Rules

A standard 5 digit numerical code has been developed for the whole of Scotland. It comprises a 4 digit identifying code, which is within an agreed range for each Health Board, and a check digit.
It is the Practice Code of the patients registered GP which is recorded in this field
It should be noted that the GP Practice code in England is 6 characters long.
The General Practice code should be right justified, with the first character a space, unless it is a valid GP Practice Code from outwith Scotland.
Points to Note

Practice code will be used to provide information to GMPs on referral activity.
The Practice Code on the patients referral or attendance should be record. If a patient changes GP practice between referral and attendance, the new Practice Code should be recorded.
Dummy practice codes are held in the reference files and are hard coded for validation. These codes are:
99942 - Patients registered with a private practice only
99957 - Patients not registered with a GP in the UK
99961 - Patients where practice code is unknown and who are not covered by codes 99942, 99957, 99976, 99981, 99995 and 99961
99976 - British armed forces patients not registered with a GP in the UK
99981 - Foreign visitors not registered with a GP in Scotland
99995 - Patients registered with a GP in England, Wales or Northern Ireland (excluding patients included under code 99942)
GPPC is not validated for SMR00 or SMR01 records from Dental Hospitals (G106H, S206H, T113H).
Cross Checks

If it is a Scottish GPPC it must be a valid practice code which is open on the clinic date (SMR00), date of arrival (SMR30) or admission date (all other record types).
If it is a practice outwith Scotland it must be a valid code on the "Rest of UK" practice reference file.
Further Information
It should be noted that patients are no longer registered with an individual GP, but with a practice.

In NHS Scotland, the practice code is a four-digit code plus a check digit with ranges of codes allocated to each Health Board. ISD maintains a GP Practice code reference file which contains up to date details of address, postcode, telephone number for each GP Practice in Scotland.

In England and Wales, the field is 6 digits therefore to accommodate cross border patient flows, this should be taken into account.

SMR Validation - General Practitioner Practice Code

Definition
The Community Health Index (CHI) is a population register, which is used in Scotland for health care purposes. The CHI number uniquely identifies a person on the index.

Points to Note

Where the CHI is used as the Health Record Identifier (Case Reference Number), please continue to record this number in both the HRI and CHI fields.
Cross Checks
None.

Further Information

The Community Health Index is a register of all patients in NHS Scotland. CHI Index contains details of all Scottish residents and exists to ensure that patients can be correctly identified, and that relevant information pertaining to a patients health is available to providers of care.

The CHI number is a unique is a 10-character numeric identifier, allocated to each patient on first registration with the system.

The CHI number should always be used to identify a patient. However, Health record identifiers, such as hospital numbers in Patient Administration Systems (PAS), may be used locally, in conjunction with the CHI number or in the absence of the CHI number, to track patients and their records.

Although there may be no number when a patient presents for treatment, there must be an allocation at some point in the episode of care as CHI is mandatory on all clinical communications.

Non-Scottish patients and other temporary residents can have a CHI number allocated if required.

Should it be required patients can contact their GP Surgery in the first instance for their individual CHI Number.

See also - Baby CHI – Babies 1 to 3

Definition
The postcode is a basic unit for identifying geographic locations. A postcode is associated with each address in the UK..

Postcode Format
A postcode has two component parts. Part one of the postcode is known as the outcode, and part two is known as the incode.

Outcode
The outcode identifies the postal area and the postal district. The postal area is represented by 1 or 2 alpha characters and the postal district is represented by 1 or 2 digits. Therefore, part 1 contains 2, 3 or 4 characters.

Incode
The incode is of length 3 characters. The postcode sector is represented by the outcode plus the first digit of the incode. The complete postcode represents the postmans walk.

Points to Note
Postcodes for Scotland

The instructions for determining a postcode given at the front of the Postcode Directories should be followed and the Postcodes entered in the spaces provided, and left justified. There should be no embedded blanks.
Postcodes as written have two parts. The first part, consisting of one or two letters and one or two numbers identifies the Post Town and Postal district. The second part, consisting of one number and two letters, identifies the Postcode Sector and postmans walk.
The postcode of the patients usual address should be entered wherever possible. If only a temporary address is known, then this should be coded.
If a postcode cannot be found using the Postcode Directory, the appropriate Postcode Enquiry office should be contacted.
Address not known. Where a patients address is not known (but the patient is not of "no fixed abode"), and all reasonable means of attempting to trace the address have been exhausted, the dummy postcode "NK01 0AA" should be used. The use of this postcode will always be queried.
The querying of postcodes valid to sector level was discontinued on 1st April 1998. The whole postcode must be valid to be accepted; if not an error will be produced.
Local Government District Dummy Postcodes can no longer be entered.
The postcode must be recorded in full
A list of all valid postcodes in Scotland, together with the permitted dummy postcodes, is held on the computer files at ISD.
If the full Postcode is not on the reference file, the record will be flagged with an error message and the postcode must be corrected.
For patients who are with the armed forces and based in the United Kingdom, use postcode of their base. For British Forces Posted Overseas who return to Scotland and go direct to hospital for treatment, use the dummy postcode BF01 0AA.
Cross Checks (applicable to SMR only)

If postcode is OS14AA, OS16AA, OS17AA, OS18AA, then Category of Patient should be 4 or 5 (i.e. overseas visitors). If not, the record will be queried.
From 1st April 2000 if postcode is BF01 0AA and the category of patient is not 3 (NHS), the record will be queried.
SMR Validation - Postcode

Definition
The surname of a person represents that part of the name of a person which indicates the family group of which the person is part.

It should be noted that in Western culture this is normally the latter part of the name of a person. However, this is not necessarily true of all cultures. This will, of course, give rise to some problems in the representation of the name. This is resolved by including with the name a preferred name format indicating amongst other things the order of various parts of the name.

Recording Rules

Surname should be entered in the character spaces provided. CAPITAL LETTERS should be used and the item left justified.
Hyphens or apostrophes occurring within a name should be entered as a separate character (but not as a first character).
Double-barrelled surnames should be entered with a hyphen between the two parts of the surname, whether or not the patient normally uses a hyphen.
In the very rare circumstances when the surname is not known, the first two character spaces should be filled with "X".

Examples
S	M	I	T	H															
D	U	R	H	A	M	-	J	O	N	E	S								
O	-	H	A	R	A														
X	X																		
Points to Note

A surname must have at least one alphabetic character.
Space for up to 20 characters is provided; it is recommended that the full 20 characters be allowed in use for future systems development.
Where a patient requires to remain anonymous, a pseudo-name, such as A N Other, should be used.

Based on UK Government Data Standards Catalogue: BSEN 7372:1993
Cross Checks
None.

Definition
A Patient Health Record Identifier is a code (set of characters) used to uniquely identify a patient within a health register or a HEALTH RECORDS SYSTEM, e.g. PAS

Recording Rules
Note: If more than 10 characters are required for the Health Record Identifier, ISD should be contacted for advice.

A Health Record Identifier should be recorded on every record - advice should be sought from your Medical Records Manager if no Health Record Identifier is available.

Example 1: 6 digits or less - The first 6 character spaces should be used. Enter preceding zeros to make the number up to 6 digits e.g. 1234 = 001234

Example 2: 7 digits or more - The number should be entered starting from the left and leaving no spaces between digits. Unused character spaces should be left blank, e.g. PT123432 = PT123432
Points to Note

Where the CHI is used as the HRI, please continue to record this number in both the HRI and CHI fields.

Definition
The GMC (General Medical Council) number is the personal identification number issued to each doctor in the UK by the General Medical Council.

Recording Rules

If this item is to be completed, it is the General Medical Council registration number (GMC number) of the referring Doctor or Dentist which should be used.
The GMC number can consist of 7 numeric or L + 6 numeric. The L format is used for limited registrations, usually overseas doctors, and in time this number could be changed to a permanent number, usually 7 numeric.
The General Dental Council (GDC) Number consists of D + 6 numeric.
The 8 digit personal identification number (PIN) allocated to Nurses and other Allied Healthcare Professionals (AHP) is used as the Nurse/AHP code. In the case of a nurse the PIN consists of an 8 character alpha/numeric code, although this format may differ for other AHPs (e.g. Podiatrists).
The GMC/GDC/PIN number should be right justified in the eight character spaces provided.
From April 2020 this data item was no longer required for national collection on SMR00.
Points to Note

The referring Doctor may not belong to the patients registered GP Practice.
Cross Checks
None.

Definition
The date on which a person was born or is officially deemed to have been born as recorded on their birth certificate.

Recording Rules
Date of birth should be entered thus:

9th February 1942
0	9	0	2	1	9	4	2
All dates must consist of eight digits by entering preceding zeros for single digits in day, month or year.

Patients age only is available
- year of birth should be calculated and day and month infilled with zero, thus:

Age 25 (in 1999): therefore year of birth = (1999-25) = 1974

0	0	0	0	1	9	7	4
Age not known
- if all avenues have been explored and neither date of birth nor age is available then the clinicians or nursing staffs estimate of age should be used to calculate year of birth. If this is not possible, refer to your Medical Records Manager

Estimated Age 27 (in 1999): therefore estimated year of birth = (1999-27) = 1972

0	0	0	0	1	9	7	2
Points to Note

The Date of Birth is allocated 8 digits to record the full year of birth.
Cross checks

Age (and consequently the Date of Birth) is an important data item and is used in a number of cross-checks, e.g.
Specialty
Diagnoses
Admission /Transfer From
Discharge/ Transfer To
Referral Received Date (SMR00 Only)
Date of Birth is also checked to be in sequence with the other dates recorded. To view sequence of dates checks please refer to Date Sequences
Date of Birth must be less than date of admission for all record types (except SMR01, where Date of Birth can equal date of admission when Significant Facility is 11 or 16).
Date of Birth may equal date of clinic or date of referral for SMR00.
SMR01 and 04, and age on admission is greater than 100 years, the record will be queried
If record is SMR02, and age on admission is less than 10 or greater than 50, the record will be queried.
If record is SMR04, and age on admission is less than 1 year, the record will be queried.
For SMR01 where specialty is AB (Geriatrics), and age on admission is less than 49 and Significant Facility is not 18, the record will be queried.
If record type is SMR01 and Specialty is AF (Paediatrics), CA (Paediatric Surgery) or D8 (Paediatric Dentistry), and age on admission is 18 or over, the record will be queried
Age is also checked with diagnoses, e.g
Senile Dementia - The current check will generate a query if the patient is less than 55 years of age.
Similarly childhood diagnoses will generate a query if the patient is greater than 16 years of age.
SMR Validation - Date of Birth

Definition
A unique identifier allocated to new referrals to a consultant led service, to enable identification of patient pathways.

Points to Note

The UCPN was initiated by the 18 Weeks RTT team and was first used by SCI Gateway Referrals in September 2009.
A UCPN should be generated for all source referrals made to a Consultant led service.
Where referrals are not received via SCI Gateway, local systems should generate a UCPN.
The format of the UCPN was defined by the SCI Gateway as SSS999999999C.
“SSS” is a 3 character alphanumeric System Source Identifiers (SSI), assigned by ISD.
“999999999” is a 9 digit sequential number.
“C” is a check digit/character calculated on the preceding 12 characters.
ISD maintains a National Reference File of System Source Identifiers (SSIs) and provides Health Boards with these codes on request.
When one referral is received with more than one referring complaint then the primary referring complaint should keep the UCPN received from SCI Gateway. This should be managed as one pathway. Further referring complaints should each have a UCPN generated by the local system. These should be managed as separate pathways, i.e. that patient has two (or more) concurrent 18 Week RTT pathways.
One UCPN may be recorded on a single SMR return.
The UCPN will be used to link SMR00 and SMR01 datasets and will enable the tracking of patients as they move between consultants, specialties, hospital settings (outpatient to inpatient) and Health Boards and will not be used by ISD for the purpose of measuring 18wRTT.
See the following site for further information: Unique Care Pathway Number (UCPN) - FAQs
E-Health
Cross Checks
None.

Definition

Priority Optional (up to four allowed, two on forms)

The consultative process indicated that Optional provision should be allowed for the future recording of lifestyle factors of interest to particular Specialties.

These are those factors inherent in a patient's way of living that may have a significant effect on their propensity to ill health or the likely success of treatment. These may include the degree of smoking, alcohol, or drug abuse, diet, exercise, and other factors indicated in the ICD10 Z chapter, or relevant Read codes.

Up to four such factors have been included, with up to six characters per factor, to allow for the use of ICD10 or Read codes.

Definition

Priority Optional (up to four allowed, two on forms)

Some interest was shown during the consultative process in the USA developments of disease staging, originally developed to classify oncology patients and now extended to all diseases typically seen in hospital inpatient and outpatient care. It allows the noting of increased severity based on the spread of the disease and the presence of complications. The Disease Category codes (3 characters) and Disease Stage codes (3 characters) area relate currently to ICD9-CM and DRG codes. They can be related to "resource" measures and "outcome" measures.

They are indicative of the possible use of the SMR Dataset for experimental and developmental purposes, and space has been allowed for these, or other, codes such as Read codes. Up to 4 codes have been included, each of up to 6 characters.
dataElements.name: Severity Measures

dataElements.description:
Definition

Priority Local

This is the charge applicable to this patient episode.

The last five fields indicated above (Contract Service Number to Contract Charge) are optional. The way in which they are used will be dependent upon local arrangements between Providers and Commissioners as part of their contract management reporting arrangements.
dataElements.name: Contract Charge

dataElements.description:
Definition

Priority Optional

Patient care events occur at different points in time; some are discrete, and some may need to be associated with others, for example, for budgeting or contracting for 'care packages' across inpatient and outpatient episodes, and for the evaluation and monitoring of the efficiency of care.

It is proposed that a separate code be included for the overall clinical problem associated with an episode, a group of episodes, or a 'care package'. For example, a diabetes condition may result in episodes associated with vascular and ophthalmological disease.

Up to six characters have been included, so as to allow for Read or ICD10 codes. The ways in which this data item may be used for 'care packages' will depend upon the definition and characteristics of such packages as agreed by Providers and Purchasers for different Specialties.
dataElements.name: Clinical Problem Identifier for Spell/Care Package

dataElements.description:
Definition

Priority Optional (up to four allowed, two on forms)

Interest was shown during the consultative process in the use of dependency measures particularly in the areas of Geriatric Long Stay (SMR Record Type 50) and Mental Health (SMR Record Type 04). Optional provision has therefore been made in the SMR Dataset for the future, or extended, use of such dependency measures as used with the Scottish Health Resource Utilisation Groups (SHRUGS), which involve the collection of data on patient characteristics at defined intervals during the period of care.

For example, with Geriatric Long Stay (SHRUGS), patient characteristics are collected from care staff who know the patient well, defined in terms of need for special care, clinically complex conditions or treatments, behavioural difficulties, and personal dependency. An algorithm is used to determine a resource use group for each patient on the basis of these characteristics.

With Mental Health (using the Dependency and Needs Information System, DANIS), similar data is collected, including major sustained training needs, complex nursing care needed, clinically complex treatments or conditions, and behavioural difficulties.

Provision has been made in the SMR Dataset for the developmental use of these measures. Up to four measures have been included, each with up to six characters, to allow for a variety of codes that may be used.
dataElements.name: Dependency Measures

dataElements.description:
Definition

Priority Local

Diagnostic Related Groups (DRG) or Health Resource Groups (HRG) may not necessarily be part of the information available following local processing of the SMR data. If the DRG/HRG is required in the contract assignments process, then arrangements have to be made locally for grouping software to be run against the ICD10 and OPCS4 coding to produce the DRG/HRG.
dataElements.name: Iso-resource Group

dataElements.description:
Definition

Priority Local

This field allows further mapping of the contracted service within a contract for invoice verification, where the database in use uses this construct. It should be left blank where there is only one contracted service under the contract.
dataElements.name: Contract Service Number

dataElements.description:
Definition

Priority Local

A patient is chronically sick or disabled if he/she is blind, deaf or dumb, or is substantially and permanently handicapped by illness, injury, or congenital deformity.

This is recorded at the time of admission and it is used under the Chronically Sick and Disabled Persons Act 1970 to record the number of such people who are accommodated inappropriately, e.g. admitted to or resident in wards intended for elderly people.

This data item may be of value for specific clinical or contracting purposes within certain Specialties.
dataElements.name: Chronic Sick/Disabled

dataElements.description:
Definition

Priority Optional (up to four allowed, two on forms)

During the consultative process it was noted that there was a strong interest from Purchasers and Providers in developing the use of outcome measures related to the individual patient episode. It was also noted that these had not yet been sufficiently developed, and could include the following:

"general" outcome measures, such as mortality within specific periods after discharge, readmission rates (to the same or other hospitals), discharges to home or other institution, and reoperation rates, etc. (These are best able to be analysed at present using the ISD SMR Record Linked database, and will be significantly extended by the SMR Dataset.)
"medium term" outcome measures, related to specific Specialties, that could only be followed up after a specified period after discharge, through follow-up appointments or by communication with the GP.
"on discharge" outcome measures, which relate the assessment on admission of the patient with the result of the treatment or operation during the period of care that the patient was under the responsibility of a particular Consultant, Department, or Hospital. This would include infection rates.
The Clinical Outcomes Working Group of CRAG (Clinical Resource and Audit Group) are proposing national guidelines and a continuing development programme for specific clinical outcome measures.

Optional provision has been made in the SMR Dataset for up to four measures to be recorded for each episode, each of up to six characters, to allow for a variety of codes, including Read codes.
dataElements.name: Outcome Measures

dataElements.description:
This section is reserved to be used for the collection of data items which are being piloted and evaluated, for specific epidemiological/ clinical research projects, and for short term surveys.

This may be used for local purposes, and for agreed national projects.
dataElements.name: Development Data Section

dataElements.description:
Definition

Priority (as below)

A contract identifier is a code which identifies each health care contract. It is a three part code:

Provider code
Purchaser code
Contract number which uniquely identifies the contract between the contracting parties


Provider Code (5 characters) - Priority Mandatory

This is a UK national code which uniquely identifies a Health Board/Health Care Provider which is an organisation acting as a direct provider of health care services. It is a legal entity, or a subset thereof, which may contract for the provision of health care, and it may operate in one or more locations within and outside hospitals.

Points to Note

When completing the provider code on ISD returns, the code of the Health Board/Health Care Provider which actually provides clinical services must be recorded.
Example
If a consultant from Health Board/Health Care Provider A visits the premises of Health Board/Health Care Provider B to provide care on outreach basis (i.e. continues to be employed by Health Board/Health Care Provider A), recorded provider should be Health Board/Health Care Provider A.

If a consultant from Health Board/ Health Care Provider A visits the premises of Health Board/Health Care Provider B to provide care and Health Board/Health Care Provider B pays for this work either directly to the consultant or to Health Board/Health Care Provider A, the consultant is thought of as temporarily employed by Health Board/Health Care Provider B and the recorded provider should be Health Board/Health Care Provider B.

Cross Checks

Must be valid provider code.

Purchaser Code (5 characters) - Priority Optional

This is a UK national code which uniquely identifies a health care organisation that commissions health care services on behalf of its residents or patients, e.g. a Health Board which is responsible for commissioning comprehensive healthcare services for its residents.

Points to Note

This field may be blank.
Cross Checks

If Purchaser Code is present, then it must be a valid code and will be validated against the organisation reference file.

Contract Number (6 characters) - Priority Local

This is an alphanumeric code which uniquely identifies the contract between the contracting parties.

Points to Note

This field may be blank.
Contract Identifier
Contract Identifier (which consists of 16 characters) should be entered thus:

Provider (first 5 digits), Purchaser (next five digits), Contract Number (final six digits).
dataElements.name: Contract Identifier

dataClasses.description: Episode Management Data
dataClasses.name: Episode Management Data

dataElements.description:
Format
Characters

Field Length
3

Priority
Mandatory

Definitions

Specialty
A Specialty is defined as a division of medicine or dentistry covering a specific area of clinical activity and identified within one of the Royal Colleges or Faculties.

Click here for a complete list of Specialties

Discipline
A Discipline is a non-medical profession related to healthcare, for which a formal training leading to a recognised professional qualification is undertaken. Examples of disciplines are physiotherapy, nursing, pharmacology.

Recording Rules
This field should be coded to the Specialty/Discipline of the consultant/GP/HCP who is in charge of the patient episode. If the consultant is formally recognised and contracted to work in more than one specialty then the patients problem or condition should dictate the specialty.

Note that this is the ONLY rule for completing this field. The designation of the beds is not used.

Specialty/Discipline comprises four characters, the first three of which are allocated by ISD for each specialty, and is mandatory for completion. For the majority of Specialty/Discipline codes, which are two characters, the 3rd character space must be left blank if the 4th character extension is used. The 4th character is an Optional extension of the code for local special interests.

The Specialty/Discipline code should be entered in the character spaces provided and left justified.

Points to Note

A separate SMR record is prepared when a patient changes Specialty, Significant Facility or Consultant on medical grounds
GPs: Patients under the care of a GP in a GP hospital must be given the Specialty code E12 (GP other than Obstetrics) regardless of whether the patients are in a short stay or long stay facility.
Staff Wards: The Specialty recorded is that of the consultant/GP in charge of the patient. Record Significant Facility as 11 (Other: including all Standard Specialty Wards, Clinical Facility 1K, Day Bed Unit 1J).
Younger Physically Disabled: Record the Specialty of the consultant in charge of the patient, which will usually be geriatric medicine. Record Significant Facility as 18 (Ward for Younger Physically Disabled) or 1E (Long Stay Unit for Care of the Elderly).
See additional notes under Significant Facility.
For SMR02 records this should reflect the speciality of the person who was responsible for the care for the mother on original admission.
Example 1- If the mother was originally admitted under the care of a midwife in an Alongside Midwifery Unit (AMU) or Freestanding Midwifery Unit (FMU), then the midwifery specialty should be recorded in this section, irrespective of whether the mother was then transferred to an Obstetric unit during labour/delivery. When a transfer has occurred Speciality should NOT be attributed to Obstetrics.

Example 2 - If the mother was originally admitted under the care of a Consultant in an Obstetric Unit then the Obstetrics specialty should be recorded here.

Cross Checks

Specialty is checked against Location Code.
Specialty is checked against Consultant.
Specialty is checked against the Patients Age (at Date of Admission).
Specialty is checked against Duration of Stay calculated between Date of Admission and Date of Discharge.
Specialty is checked against Record Type
Specialty is checked against Significant Facility.

Location Code
Significant Facility
SMR Record Type

dataElements.description:
Format
Characters

Field Length
1

Priority
Mandatory

Definition
Patient (administrative) category refers to a patients status regarding payment for NHS services. It indicates whether (s)he is a category II patient, NHS patient, private patient (paying), amenity patient, or an overseas visitor who is or is not liable to pay for treatment.

Points to Note

An amenity patient is an inpatient who undertakes to pay for the use of an amenity bed, i.e. accommodation made available for patients who give an undertaking to pay charges determined by the Trust in single rooms or side wards which are not for the time being needed by any patient on medical grounds. NB. Code 1 Amenity is not applicable to SMR00 (outpatients).
An overseas visitor is a patient who is defined under section 98 of the NHS (Scotland) Act 1978 and is charged, where appropriate, in accordance with the guidance given in NHS Circular No. 1982 (Gen)29, as amended.

Note
Trusts have a statutory duty to identify overseas visitors and make charges in accordance with section 98 of the Act.
An overseas visitor may opt to become a private patient.

Overseas visitors who pay fees for treatment should be coded 4 - Overseas visitor liable to pay for treatment. Overseas visitors who do not pay fees for treatment should be coded 5 - Overseas visitors not liable to pay - reciprocal arrangements.
An overseas visitor may opt to become a private patient.
If an overseas visitor has opted to become a private patient, code 2 should be used.
Code 2 should be used where patients pay for all or part of their treatment.
Patients referred by a court for NHS psychiatric assessment where the court pays should be recorded as NHS code 3 rather than Paying code 2.
Cross Checks

Category of Patient - Overseas Visitors codes 4 & 5 will be checked against postcode and if it is not one of the dummy codes for overseas patients a query will be produced.
Category of Patient is cross-checked with Record Type.
For SMR00 the Patient Category must not be 1 (Amenity). (01/04/2000)
For SMR04 the Patient Category must not be 1 (Amenity). (01/04/2008)
Codes and Values: Patient category (Code order)
1 Amenity
2 Paying
3 NHS
4 Overseas visitor - liable to pay for treatment
5 Overseas visitor - not liable to pay (reciprocal arrangements)
8 Other (including Hospice)

SMR Validation - Patient Category

Definition
Admission/transfer from indicates the source of admission, or type of location from which a patient has been admitted.

Points to Note

The no additional detail code assignments are for use only when the lack of detailed information about the admission prevents the use of one of the more detailed codes provided.
Patients on pass from a Mental Health or Long Stay specialty are TRANSFERRED to an acute specialty ONLY if the acute episode is the reason for the patient being on pass. Patients who are ALREADY on pass who undergo an acute episode during their period of pass are ADMITTED to the acute episode. Please refer to Specialty Grouping for Transfer Codes.
If a patient is involved in an accident and returns to their usual place of residence before they are admitted to hospital, the admit/transfer code should be one of the Private Residence Codes (10-19) or Residence (Institution) codes (20-29).
Patients who are admitted from a day hospital or an outpatient clinic, whether held in the hospital to which they are admitted or in another hospital should be coded to the location of the start of the journey to hospital.
Code 68 should be used when a patient is admitted after an RTA, or from a public place without returning to their usual place of residence.
Codes 41 and 51 apply only to patients who were admitted to an Accident and Emergency Ward before being transferred. Patients admitted following an attendance at an Accident and Emergency Department should be recorded using one of the residence codes or code 68 Other type of location depending upon where the patient was prior to their Accident and Emergency attendance.
Cross Checks

Admit/Transfer from is cross-checked with Record Type.
Admit/Transfer from is cross-checked with age.

Definition
Admission/transfer from - location gives the location code, where appropriate, of the location from where a patient is admitted.

Each location in Scotland, at which events pertinent to the NHSScotland take place, is allocated a Location Code. Locations include hospitals, health centres, clinics, NHS board offices, private nursing homes, homes for the elderly, children’s homes and schools. The code is a five character code and is maintained by ISD.

Recording Rules
Where applicable, enter the Location code as follows:

Ninewells Hospital =

T	1	0	1	H

dataElements.description:
Format
Characters

Field Length
1

Priority
Mandatory

Definition
Management of Patient indicates the patient type and the pattern of bed use of a patient for SMR Record Types 01, 02, and 04.

Points to Note

Rules for the generation of each of the SMR record types are to be found at the beginning of each Specialty Specific Section.
Management of Patient codes: 2,4,6 are all types of Day Case.
Management of Patient codes: 1,3,5,7, A and B are all types of Inpatient.
Where a patient comes in as a day case and stays overnight (3, 5, 7) and then transfers, the subsequent episodes should be coded 1 (Inpatient).
Code A covers those patients who are admitted to or transferred to the Day Bed Unit as an emergency for a day case procedure. They are admitted as inpatients and discharged the same day as admission. Code A does not cover patients who are inpatients within a hospital and as part of their treatment plan are transferred to the Day Bed Unit or other clinical area for a procedure and then transferred back to their original ward on the same day. The correct code in these circumstances would be either 2, 4 or 6 depending upon the type of facility the patient was admitted to for the day case procedure. These are sometimes referred to as Embedded Day Cases.
Where a patient is admitted as Management of Patient code A (Inpatient admitted to and discharged from a DBU on the same day) and stays overnight the Management of Patient code should be amended to code 3, the subsequent episodes should be coded to 1 (Inpatient).
Cross Checks

Management of Patient is cross-checked with Record Type.
Example: Codes 1-7, A and B are valid on SMR01
Management of Patient is cross-checked with Length of Stay.
Example: Codes 2, 4, 6 and A must have a length of stay = 0 days
Management of Patient is cross-checked with Admission Reason.
Example: If Admission Reason 21, Management of Patient must be Codes 1-7 or A
Management of Patient is crosschecked with Record Type.
Example: MoP must be blank if Record Type = 00
Codes and Values: Management of Patient (Code order)

0 - Home Birth SMR02
1 - Inpatients (except for categories 3,5,7 and A below)
2 - Day Case in Day Bed Unit (except where retained overnight or longer)
3 - Inpatient originally admitted as a Day Case in Day Bed Unit, then moved to Inpatient Ward for intended overnight retention or longer
4 - Day Case in Inpatient Ward (except where retained overnight or longer)
5 - Inpatient originally admitted as Day Case in Inpatient Ward and retained overnight or longer
6 - Day Case - Other than in Day Bed Unit or Inpatient Ward (except where retained overnight or longer)
7 - Inpatient originally admitted as Day Case Other, then moved to Inpatient Ward for intended overnight retention or longer
A - Inpatient admitted to and discharged from a Day Bed Unit on the same day
B - Hospital at Home

Definition
Waiting list type indicates whether or not a patient who is admitted for inpatient/day case care is on a waiting list for the condition giving rise to the admission.

Points to Note

Code 8 should be used for emergency and urgent admissions who are not on a waiting list for the condition prompting admission.
Code 8 may also be used for planned transfers although it is good recording practice to record the date the decision was made to transfer the patient as this will enable any wait the patient has experienced to be identified.
If code 8 is used, Admission Type should not = 10, 12 or 19.
Cross Checks

Waiting List Type is cross checked against Record Type. It is not applicable to SMR02 and SMR00.
Waiting List Type is cross-checked against Waiting List Date, e.g. if Waiting List Type is 8, Waiting List Date must be blank; if Waiting List Type is 1 Waiting List Date must be present.
If Waiting List Type is 8, Admission Type must not = 11 (Elective Admission)
Codes and Values: Waiting List Type (Code order)
1 True waiting list
2 Planned repeat waiting list
8 Not on waiting list (see points to note)
9 Not known (this is allowed locally as a holding code until the correct code is assigned and is not valid centrally)
